title: Chhath Puja
hero_image_alt: Devotees standing in water worshipping the sun
short_description: An ancient, rigorous Vedic festival dedicated to the Sun God, observed with river rituals at sunset and sunrise.
long_description:
Chhath Puja is an ancient Hindu Vedic festival dedicated to the Sun God (Surya) and Chhathi Maiya. It is unique because it involves no idols and no priests; the devotee alone performs the rituals. Predominantly celebrated in Bihar, Jharkhand, and UP, it is a four-day period of extreme purity and discipline. 

The main rituals involve fasting without water for 36 hours and standing in waist-deep water to offer 'Arghya' (oblations) to the setting sun (Sandhya Arghya) and the rising sun (Usha Arghya). The offerings include seasonal fruits, sugarcane, and the famous 'Thekua' (sweet wheat cookie), all arranged in bamboo winnows. It is a mesmerizing sight to see millions of women in colorful sarees standing in the river as holding their offerings, waiting for the sun's rays.
significance: Thanksgiving to the Sun God for sustaining life on Earth.
key_rituals: Nahay Khay: Ritual bath and a pure meal of bottle gourd and rice.
Kharna: Fasting all day and eating kheer-roti in the evening.
Sandhya Arghya: Offering prayers to the setting sun.
Usha Arghya: Offering prayers to the rising sun.

practical_info.dress_tips: It is respectful to dress conservatively. Remove shoes before stepping near the puja area.
practical_info.safety_tips: River banks are slippery and crowded. Do not enter the water if you can't swim.
practical_info.accessibility_notes: Ghats (steps) are very difficult for wheelchairs.

faqs.a: Yes! After the final morning offering, 'Prasad' is distributed to everyone. It is considered a blessing.
It is believed that even a slight mistake in purity can bring bad luck, hence the extreme discipline.
